body:
@jorisvandenbossche what do you think? we can setup a template and some automation
and make it easier for people to contribute.
We can build some automation and setup a template that'll let us recast the content into
docstrings, or cross-reference fom them. With tags and automated building on travis,
it can become a live thing and very easy for contributors to join in.

I'm willing to put in work building the groundwork, but I need to know It's likely to be
embraced by other contributors as well.

Some thoughts:
- I think already a good goal to work towards would be to expand the docstrings.  
  For me it's one of the main issue with tha pandas docs at the moment to have better docstrings. I had a draft issue to submit about this (to start the dicsussion about this, and to see how we could engage the community), but did not yet finish it. 
- So if we want "a catalog of code examples by method", I think we should start with the docstrings rather than a new section in the docs (and make sure we link often to the docstrings in the docs)
- How do you envisage the template/automation to make it easier to contribute? I'm not fuly understanding what you're saying?  
  Some web interface where people could provide examples without the need to learn git/submit PR? (maybe see also this https://github.com/pv/pydocweb/tree/master/doc and http://docs.scipy.org/numpy/Front%20Page/ which is something in this direction for numpy/scipy. But it seems it's not used that much anymore (in favor of PRs via github I assume)) Or have a seperate file with these example which are inserted in the docstrings (to prevent the docstrings in the code itself becomes to large)?
- What do you mean with "making it easilyy accessible while working in ipython"?

But improving the docs in this area is important, and certainly worth thinking about this how we could best handle it.

easily accessible in ipython means just that. That while coding, you can launch
the examples page for a method directly from the session.

I was not proposing a new section in the docs, but a new doc sub-project.
It's easier to build a system that enforces structured examples which we
can process, then it is to accept docstring changes and then extract out
just the relevent bits and turn them into web pages.

Beyond a certain length, I don't think docstrings are useful, I certainly
struggle with them in ipython. webpages can be much more detailed
and better presented.

Linking from the docs to docstrings is a bizarre idea IMO, the converse 
is not, nor is `pd.apropos(df.merge)` -> launch firefox.

But perhaps docstrings are a fine solution and doing something more 
elaborate is going too far.

I'll close, we can pick it up someday if we want to.
